description: Churchyard of the ancient Parish Church of St Mary, Walthamstow; an area of three & one third acres containing over 1300 monuments including four Grade II listed tombs. Burial records date from 1743.

events.name: Churchyard Trails: Stories from Walthamstow's Past
events.notes: Weather dependent ~ may be cancelled at short notice if wet. Due to uneven terrain, we regret the event is not suitable for those with limited mobility and wheelchair users. Please wear suitable footwear. Unsuitable for those aged under 10 years of age.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: St Mary’s Church started as a 12th C Norman building, built around 1108 as a manorial church by Ralph de Toni, son of the standard bearer of William the Conqueror. It is the oldest building in Walthamstow and stands at the heart of the first conservation area in the London Borough of Waltham Forest, Walthamstow Village. For over 900 years, the church has been at the centre of faith and community in Walthamstow.

The Churchyard which surrounds the building encloses three and one-third acres; of the approximately 26,000 burials 16,000 since, the mid 18th C, are recorded in the registers. There are over 1300 monuments, including four Grade II listed tombs, with the oldest legible monument dated 1710.

factsheet.heading: Notable Monuments and Memorials
paragraphs: The four Grade II listed tombs are: Wise (1710), Rigg (1754), Solly (1776) and Morley Wilson (1847). There are several Commonwealth War Grave Commission graves across the site. Many other fine monuments are to be found, some of which will be included in the Churchyard Trails.

factsheet.heading: Cultural
paragraphs: The stories of people buried here across several centuries reflect the changing nature of society in Walthamstow; from rural Essex village to a place where City merchants and wealthy businessmen had their country residences.
Samuel Pepys is known to have attended services at St Mary's on two occasions and to have drunk ale with Sir Wm Penn and Sir Wm Batten at the church stile in the churchyard.
Rev William Wilson, vicar 1822-1848, a pioneer of infant education, erected the first purpose built C of E Infants' School in the country on glebe land opposite the church in 1828.

factsheet.heading: Other Information
paragraphs: The churchyard is the second largest enclosed green space in the local area; many people have used it as a place of refuge and peace during the recent Covid pandemic. The churchyard is being managed to be a haven for wildlife and biodiversity and in 2020 was awarded a Silver-Gilt in the Churchyard category of London In Bloom.

location.address: Church End (top of Church Hill), Walthamstow, E17 9RL
travel_info: Nearest train: Walthamstow Central, Walthamstow Queens Road, Wood Street

name: St. Mary's Church, Walthamstow Village
